function.name: get-database-ids
function.summary: This function returns all the database IDs from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: get-host-ids
function.summary: This function returns all the host IDs from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: get-group-ids
function.summary: This function returns all the group IDs from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: get-forest-ids
function.summary: This function returns all the forest IDs from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: get-appserver-ids
function.summary: This function returns all the appserver IDs from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: get-configuration
function.summary: Loads the admin configuration into memory for use by other functions in the Admin module.
function.usage: The configuration is loaded into memory only as it is needed, so it might not contain the entire configuration at any given moment. It loads only the parts of the configuration that are needed at the time they are needed to perform other Admin module operations that specified in the XQuery request. Therefore, if you execute the function without calling any other Admin module functions, it will return the empty sequence (because it never needed any of the config information to perform any of the Admin module operations).

function.name: save-configuration-without-restart
function.summary: This function saves a configuration specification to the cluster configuration files, without restarting MarkLogic Server. If you use this function to save any changes that require a server restart ("cold" changes such as App Server port assignment changes), then the changes will not take effect until the next time MarkLogic Server restarts (although they will be saved in the configuration). If you want MarkLogic Server to automatically restart when needed, use admin:save-configurationinstead.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.usage: The return value is a list of the host IDs that need to be restarted in order for the changes to take effect.

function.name: save-configuration
function.summary: This function saves a configuration specification to the cluster configuration files. It restarts MarkLogic Server for "cold" administrative tasks only (for example, for App Server port assignment changes). If you do not want those "cold" administrative tasks to automatically restart MarkLogic Server, use admin:save-configuration-without-restartinstead.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

function.name: restart-hosts
function.summary: This function restarts MarkLogic Server for the specified hosts.

params.param: The host ID(s) for the host(s) you want to restart. For example, xdmp:host()returns the ID for the current host.

function.name: database-delete
function.summary: This function deletes the configuration from the specified database(s). It does not delete the configuration or data for any forests attached to the deleted database(s).

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id(s) for the specified database(s) (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).

function.usage: Any database whose ID you pass into this function must not have any appservers targeting it when the transaction begins, otherwise an exception is thrown. If you need to delete the database, make sure no appserver targets the database in a separate transaction before calling this function.

function.name: database-create
function.summary: This function creates a new database specification.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The name the database to create. The name must not be used by any other database in the cluster.
The ID of the security database (for example, xdmp:database("Security")used by this database.
The ID of the schemas database (for example, xdmp:database("Schemas")used by this database.

function.name: database-copy
function.summary: This function creates a new database specification with the same settings as the database with the specified ID. The new database configuration will have the specified name.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database to copy (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The name of the new database to create.

function.name: database-detach-forest
function.summary: This function detaches the specified forest from the specified database.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The ID of the forest. For example, xdmp:forest("myForest")specified the ID for a forest named "myForest".

function.name: database-attach-forest
function.summary: This function attaches the specified forest to the specified database.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The ID of the forest. For example, xdmp:forest("myForest")specified the ID for a forest named "myForest".

function.usage: Any forest whose ID you pass into this function must exist when the transaction begins, otherwise an exception is thrown. If you need to create the forest, do so in a separate transaction before using them in this function.

function.name: database-get-backups
function.summary: This function returns the scheduled backups for the specified database from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("mydatabase")).

function.name: database-weekly-backup
function.summary: This function constructs a weekly scheduled backup.

params.param: The directory where the backup will be saved to.
The how many weeks between each backup.
The day(s) of the week. Must be a sequence of zero or more of monday, tuesday, wednesday, thusday, friday, saturday, sunday.
A time for the scheduled backup to start.
The maximum number of backups to keep in the backup directory.
Whether to backup the security database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the schemas database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the triggers database alongside the current backup.
If set to false, do not include the replicas in the backup. The default is true, which means to include all replicas in the backup.
Whether or not to enable journal archiving. Defaults to false.
Path for where archived journals are stored. Defaults to the backup data directory.
Maximum difference in seconds that the archived journal can lag behind its forest's active journal. Defaults to 900.

function.name: database-monthly-backup
function.summary: This function constructs a monthly scheduled backup.

params.param: The directory where the backup will be saved to.
The number of months to elapse between each backup.
The day of the month the backup will happen (between 1 and 31)
A time for the scheduled backup to start.
The maximum number of backups to keep in the backup directory.
Whether to backup the security database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the schemas database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the triggers database alongside the current backup.
If set to false, do not include the replicas in the backup. The default is true, which means to include all replicas in the backup.
Whether or not to enable journal archiving. Defaults to false.
Path for where archived journals are stored. Defaults to the backup data directory.
Maximum difference in seconds that the archived journal can lag behind its forest's active journal. Defaults to 900.

function.name: database-one-time-backup
function.summary: This function constructs a one-time backup.

params.param: The directory where the backup will be saved to.
The starting dateTime of the scheduled backup.
The maximum number of backups to keep in the backup directory.
Whether to backup the security database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the schemas database alongside the current backup.
Whether to backup the triggers database alongside the current backup.
If set to false, do not include the replicas in the backup. The default is true, which means to include all replicas in the backup.
Whether or not to enable journal archiving. Defaults to false.
Path for where archived journals are stored. Defaults to the backup data directory.
Maximum difference in seconds that the archived journal can lag behind its forest's active journal. Defaults to 900.

function.name: database-add-backup
function.summary: This function adds scheduled backup specifications for a database to a configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("mydatabase")).
The scheduled backup specification(s), typically the result of an admin:database-one-time-backupor an admin:database-monthly-backupor an admin:database-weekly-backupcall

function.name: database-delete-backup
function.summary: This function deletes scheduled backup specifications for a database from a configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("mydatabase")).
The scheduled backup(s) to delete. Typically, the result of an admin:database-get-backupscall.

function.name: database-recurring-merge-blackout
function.summary: This function constructs a merge-blackout specification.

params.param: The maximum number of megabytes for a merge.
The CPU scheduler priority for merges. Must be one of normalor lower.
The day(s) of the week. Must be a sequence of zero or more of monday, tuesday, wednesday, thusday, friday, saturday, sunday.
A time for the merge blackout to start.
A time for the merge blackout to end.
The amount of time for the blackout to last.

params.param: The maximum number of megabytes for a merge.

The starting dateTime of the merge blackout.
The ending dateTime of the merge blackout.
The amount of time for the blackout to last.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.

The merge blackout specification(s), typically the result of an admin:database-one-time-merge-blackoutor an admin:database-recurring-merge-blackoutcall

function.summary: This function deletes a merge blackout specification for a database from a configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The merge blackout(s) to delete. Typically, the result of an admin:database-get-merge-blackoutscall.

function.name: database-range-element-index
function.summary: This function constructs a range element index specification.

params.param: A valid type for the range index. Must be one of: int, unsignedInt, long, unsignedLong, float, double, decimal, dateTime, time, date, gYearMonth, gYear, gMonth, gDay, yearMonthDuration, dayTimeDuration, string, anyURI, or point.
The namespace URI.
The local name for the node.
The collation URI (for example, http://marklogic.com/collation/). The collation is only needed for string and anyURI indexes; for other indexes, specify the empty string ("") for this parameter.
A boolean specifying whether to maintain value postions in this index (used with co-occurrences).

function.name: database-range-field-index
function.summary: This function constructs a range field index specification.

params.param: A valid type for the range index. Must be one of: int, unsignedInt, long, unsignedLong, float, double, decimal, dateTime, time, date, gYearMonth, gYear, gMonth, gDay, yearMonthDuration, dayTimeDuration, string, anyURI, or point.
The name for the field.
The collation URI (for example, http://marklogic.com/collation/). The collation is only needed for string and anyURI indexes; for other indexes, specify the empty string ("") for this parameter.
A boolean specifying whether to maintain value postions in this index (used with co-occurrences).

function.name: database-get-range-element-indexes
function.summary: This function returns the range element indexes specification(s) for the specified database from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
An element range index specification, typically the result of an admin:database-range-element-indexcall.

function.name: database-add-range-field-index
function.summary: This function adds a range field index to the specified database in the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
An field range index specification, typically the result of an admin:database-range-field-indexcall.

function.name: database-delete-range-element-index
function.summary: This function deletes a range element index for the specified database in the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
An element range index specification, typically the result of an admin:database-range-element-indexcall.

function.usage: Note that the index specification to delete must exist in the configuration exactly as specified, even if the specification includes multiple QNames. If you have a range index configuration that specifies multiple QNames in a single entry, then if you want to delete the index for only one of the QNames, you must first delete the range index specification with multiple QNames and then add the indexes that you do not want to delete. To see the specifications as they are stored in the configuration, use admin:database-get-range-element-index.

The namespace of the parent element for the attribute.
The local name of the parent element for the attribute.
The namespace URI.
The local name for the node.
The collation URI (for example, http://marklogic.com/collation/. The collation is only needed for string and anyURI indexes; for other indexes, specify the empty string ("") for this parameter.
A boolean specifying whether to maintain value postions in this index (used with co-occurrences).

An element attribute range index specification, typically the result of an admin:database-range-element-attribute-indexcall.

function.usage: Note that the index specification to delete must exist in the configuration exactly as specified, even if the specification includes multiple QNames. If you have a range index configuration that specifies multiple QNames in a single entry, then if you want to delete the index for only one of the QNames, you must first delete the range index specification with multiple QNames and then add the indexes that you do not want to delete. To see the specifications as they are stored in the configuration, use admin:database-get-range-element-attribute-index.

function.name: database-geospatial-element-index
function.summary: This function constructs a geospatial element index specification.

params.param: The namespace URI.
The local name for the node.
The coordinate system. Must be one of wgs84or raw.
A boolean specifying whether to maintain value postions in this index (used with co-occurrences).

The point format in the data: "point" means latitude precedes longitude (this is the default); "long-lat-point" means longitude precedes latitude. To use the default value of "point", simply omit this parameter. Do not specify an empty string.

function.name: database-get-geospatial-element-indexes
function.summary: This function returns the geospatial element indexes specification(s) for the specified database from the configuration.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
A geospatial element index specification, typically the result of an admin:database-geospatial-element-indexcall.

params.param: The namespace of the parent element for the attribute.
The local name of the parent element for the attribute.

The local name for the node.
The coordinate system. Must be one of wgs84or raw.
A boolean specifying whether to maintain value postions in this index (used with co-occurrences).

The point format in the data: "point" means latitude precedes longitude (this is the default); "long-lat-point" means longitude precedes latitude. To use the default value of "point", simply omit this parameter. Do not specify an empty string.

function.name: database-set-large-size-threshold
function.summary: This function sets the threshold at which binary documents in the specified database should be handled as binary large objects (BLOBs). Binary documents less than or equal to the threshold are treated as small binary objects, stored in stands. Binary documents larger than the threshold are stored in the Large Data Directory for more efficient memory consumption.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The size in kilobytes beyond which binary documents are treated as binary large objects (BLOBs) and stored in the Large Data Directory. The default is 1 MB.

function.usage:
Binary documents with size less than or equal to the configured threshold are treated as small binary objects and stored in stands. The entire contents of a small binary document is cached in memory. Binary documents larger than the threshold are stored in the Large Data Directory for more efficient memory usage. For details about small vs. large binaries, see "Binary Format" in the Application Developer's Guide.
The threshold value is in kilobytes and must be in the range:
128 KB <= threshold <= 512 MB on 64-bit systems
128 KB <= threshold <= 128 MB on 32-bit systems
The location of the Large Data Directory may be configured during forest creation by setting the "large data directory" property on the Forest configuration page of the Admin Interface, or by passing a large-data-directoryparameter to admin:forest-create.

function.name: database-set-locking
function.summary: This function sets the locking setting for the specified database in the configuration. When set to strict, locking enforces mutual exclusion on existing documents and on new documents. When set to fast, locking enforces mutual exclusion on existing documents but not on new documents. When set to off, locking does not enforce mutual exclusion on existing documents or on new documents.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The new locking value. Must be one of strict, fast, or off.

function.name: database-set-journaling
function.summary: This function sets the journaling setting for the specified database in the configuration. When set to strict, the journal protects against MarkLogic Server process failures, host operating system kernel failures, and host hardware failures. When set to fast, the journal protects against MarkLogic Server process failures but not against host operating system kernel failures or host hardware failures. When set to off, the journal does not protect against MarkLogic Server process failures, host operating system kernel failures, or host hardware failures.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).
The new journaling value. Must be one of strict, fast, or off.

The difference between this function and xdmp:database()is that the ID from this function can come from a database that has not yet been saved (that is, from a database that has been created in the same query with the Admin library but has not yet been saved to the cluster configuration files). This ID enables you to completely configure a newly created database without the need to first save the configuration.

function.name: database-get-locking
function.summary: This function returns the locking setting for the specified database in the configuration. When set to strict, locking enforces mutual exclusion on existing documents and on new documents. When set to fast, locking enforces mutual exclusion on existing documents but not on new documents. When set to off, locking does not enforce mutual exclusion on existing documents or on new documents.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).

function.name: database-get-journaling
function.summary: This function returns the journaling setting for the specified database in the configuration. When set to strict, the journal protects against MarkLogic Server process failures, host operating system kernel failures, and host hardware failures. When set to fast, the journal protects against MarkLogic Server process failures but not against host operating system kernel failures or host hardware failures. When set to off, the journal does not protect against MarkLogic Server process failures, host operating system kernel failures, or host hardware failures.

params.param: A configuration specification, typically as returned from one of the Admin module functions.
The id of the database (for example, xdmp:database("myDatabase")).

function.name: database-included-element
function.summary: This function constructs an included element specification.

params.param: The namespace URI. Specify an empty string if the element is in no namespace.
The local name for the node.
The query weight to use in relavance calculations.
The namespace for the attribute to constrain on. Specify an empty string if there is no attribute to constrain on or if the attribute is in no namespace.
The local name of the attribute to constrain on. Specify an empty string if there is no attribute to constrain on.
The value for the attribute to constrain on (only attributes with this value). Specify an empty string if there is no attribute to constrain on.

function.name: database-excluded-element
function.summary: This function constructs an excluded element specification.

params.param: The namespace URI. Specify an empty string if the element is in no namespace.
The local name for the node.
The namespace URI for the constraining attribute.
The localname for the constraining attribute.
The value for the constraing attribute.

function.usage: If the third parameter is included, the fourth and fifth must also be included. These parameters are for constraining the excluded element based on a particular attribute value.

function.name: database-field
function.summary: This function constructs a field specification.

params.param: The name of the field.
A boolean value, true to start including at the root, false to not include until an included element is reached.

The name of the field.
The new stemmed search value. Must be one of basic, advanced, decompounding, or off. It must be equal to or greater than the database setting. The empty sequence turns this setting off for the field.
