Database ID in which the module is located. If the module is on the filesystem (in the Modules directory), specify xs:unsignedLong(0).

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: get-privilege
function.summary: Returns a sec:privilege element corresponding to a privilege identified by ($action,$kind). If no such privilege is found, an error is returned.

params.param: Action protected by this privilege. For an Execute Privilege, this is usually a URI describing an activity. For a URI Privilege, this is a base URI used to filter database activities with certain document URIs.

function.name: user-set-default-permissions
function.summary: Sets the default permissions for a user with name $user-name.

params.param: The name of the user.
New permissions. If the empty sequence is provided, deletes the existing permissions.

usage.p: If a user with name $user-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: get-distinct-permissions
function.summary: Returns a sequence of permission elements made up of a concatenation of $output-perms and the distinct permission elements of $input-perms.

params.param: The input permissions.
The output permissions. This is typically an empty sequence.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: role-set-default-permissions
function.summary: Sets the default permissions for a role with name $role-name.

params.param: The name of the role to which the default permissions are set.
New permissions. If the empty sequence is provided, deletes the existing permissions.

usage.p: If a role with name $role-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: user-get-default-permissions
function.summary: Returns a sequence of permission elements correspondinig to the user's default permissions.

params.param: The name of a user.

usage.p: If a user with name $user-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:user-get-default-permissions("Jim")

function.summary: Returns a sequence of permission elements correspondinig to the role's default permissions.

usage.p: If a role with name $role-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: user-set-default-collections
function.summary: Sets the default collections of a user with name $user-name to $collections.

params.param: The name of a user.
A sequence of collections.

usage.p: If a user with name $user-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: role-set-default-collections
function.summary: Sets the default collections of a role with name $role-name to $collections.

params.param: The name of a role.
A sequence of collections.

usage.p: If a role with name $role-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: get-collection
function.summary: Gets the security document corresponding to a protected collection with uri equal to $uri.

params.param: The URI of a collection.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:get-collection("http://marklogic.com/cpf/domains")
=>
<sec:collection xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security"> <sec:collection-id>403495114666638078</sec:collection-id> <sec:uri>http://marklogic.com/cpf/domains</sec:uri> </sec:collection>

function.name: protect-collection
function.summary: Protects a collection $uri with the given permissions ($permissions). Returns the unique id of the protected collection. If the protected collection at the specified URI does not exist, it is created.

params.param: The URI of a collection.
Permissions governing the collection.

usage.p: If $uri is empty or can not be cast as an xs:AnyURI, an error is raised.
If a collection with the same uri is already protected, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: unprotect-collection
function.summary: Removes the protection of a collection $uri. This does not remove the collection or any of its documents, but it does remove the protected collection from the security database.

params.param: The URI of the collection from which to remove protections.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: collection-set-permissions
function.summary: Sets the permissions of a protected collection identified by $uri to $permissions.

params.param: The URI of a collection.
New permissions. If the empty sequence is provided, deletes the existing permissions.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: collection-add-permissions
function.summary: Add the permissions $permissions to the protected collection identified by $uri.

params.param: The URI of a collection.
New permissions to add to that protected collection. If $permissions is the empty sequence, the function will have no effect.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: collection-remove-permissions
function.summary: Removes the permissions $permissions from the protected collection identified by $uri.

params.param: The URI of a collection.
Permissions to be removed from that protected collection. If $permissions is the empty sequence, the function will have no effect.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: collection-get-permissions
function.summary: Returns a sequence of permission elements corresponding to the current permissions granted to the protected collection identified by $uri.

params.param: The URI of a collection.

usage.p: If a protected collection with uri equal to $uri is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:collection-get-permissions("http://marklogic.com/dev_modules")
=>
<sec:permission xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security"> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>5444982746628127945</sec:role-id> </sec:permission> <sec:permission xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security"> <sec:capability>insert</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>5444982746628127945</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>

function.name: user-privileges
function.summary: Returns a set of privilege elements corresponding to all privileges that a user has. (roles are flattened to give a complete set of privileges).

params.param: The name of a user.

usage.p: If a user with name equal to $user-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:user-privileges("Jim")
=>
<sec:privilege xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security"> <sec:privilege-id>12387631775818383068</sec:privilege-id> <sec:privilege-name>xdmp:save</sec:privilege-name> <sec:action>http://marklogic.com/xdmp/privileges/xdmp-save</sec:action> <sec:role-ids> <sec:role-id>13749738523688002780</sec:role-id> </sec:role-ids> <sec:kind>execute</sec:kind> </sec:privilege> (: ..... and all other privileges assigned to "jim." :)

function.name: role-privileges
function.summary: Returns a set of privilege elements corresponding to all privileges that a role has. (Roles are flattened to give a complete set of privileges).

params.param: The name of a role.

usage.p: If a role with name equal to $role-name is not found, an error is raised.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:role-privileges("Developer")
=>
<sec:privilege xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security"> <sec:privilege-id>12387631775818383068</sec:privilege-id> <sec:privilege-name>xdmp:save</sec:privilege-name> <sec:action>http://marklogic.com/xdmp/privileges/xdmp-save</sec:action> <sec:role-ids> <sec:role-id>13749738523688002780</sec:role-id> </sec:role-ids> <sec:kind>execute</sec:kind> </sec:privilege> (: ..... and all other privileges assigned to "Developer." :)

function.name: security-installed
function.summary: Returns fn:true() if security has been installed on the current database. Otherwise, returns false.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: uid-for-name
function.summary: Returns the uids for the named user or () if no such user exists.

params.param: The named user.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:uid-for-name("Jim")
=>
18325468190304151823

function.name: get-user-names
function.summary: Returns sequence of unique sec:user-name's that corresponds to the sequence of user IDs $user-ids. Duplicate IDs return a single name.

params.param: A sequence of user IDs.

usage.p: If a user ID in $user-ids does not correspond to an existing user, an error is returned.
This function must be executed against the security database.

function.example:
(: execute this against the security database :) xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security" at "/MarkLogic/security.xqy";
sec:get-user-names((18325468190304151823, 5673246250406350379, 11765239768744971597))
=>
<sec:user-name xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security">Jim</sec:user-name> <sec:user-name xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security">Sue</sec:user-name> <sec:user-name xmlns:sec="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security">Tom</sec:user-name>

function.name: set-realm
function.summary: Changes the realm of this security database to $realm. If the realm is different from the old value this function also invalidates all the existing digest passwords since they will no longer work with the new realm. Warning: this invalidates all user's digest passwords, including the user running this function and users of the Admin Interface (if the Admin Interface is set to digest authentication, which is the default setting); once a user's digest password is invalidated, that user will no longer be able to log in with digest authentication.

params.param: The new realm name to which the security database name is changed.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: check-admin
function.summary: Throws an error if the current user does not have the admin role.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: security-version
function.summary: Returns the current version of the security database.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: get-compartments
function.summary: This function returns a list of all of the compartments.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: role-get-compartment
function.summary: This function returns the compartment for the specified role.

params.param: The name of the role.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: compartment-get-roles
function.summary: This function returns a list of roles in the specifed compartment.

params.param: The name of the compartment.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: validate-permissions
function.summary: This function throws the SEC_NOPERMCAP exception if a permission has no capability specified and it throws the SEC-NOPERMROLEID exception if there is no role specified in the permission.

params.param: Zero or more permission elements to check.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: role-exists
function.summary: This function returns true if the specified role exists in the security database.

params.param: The role name.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: user-exists
function.summary: This function returns true if the specified user exists in the security database.

params.param: The user name.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: privilege-exists
function.summary: This function returns true if the specified privilege exists.

params.param: The URI of the privilege.
The kind of privilege: "execute" or uri".

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: amp-exists
function.summary: This function returns true if the specified amp exists in the security database.

params.param: The namespace for the amped function.
The local-name of the amped function.
The URI of the module containing the amped function.
The database ID of the module containing the amped function.

usage.p: This function must be executed against the security database.

function.name: user-get-last-password-date
function.summary: This function returns the time of the most recent password change for the specified user. If the password for the user has not been changed since the upgrade to 4.2, there is no history, so an empty sequence will be returned. If the user does not exist, an exception is thrown.

params.param: The name of the user to check.

function.name: user-get-password-extra
function.summary: This function returns the extra information for the specified user. If the user does not exist, an exception is thrown.

params.param: The name of the user for whom to return the extra information.

function.name: user-set-password-extra
function.summary: This function sets extra information for the specified user. If the user does not exist, an exception is thrown.

params.param: The name of the user for whom to set the extra information.
The extra information to be set for the user.

function.name: load
function.summary: Add the words from the file specified in $path to the dictionary at $uri. If a document exists with the specified URI, it is replaced with this one. Note that words that are 64 characters or greater will never be returned as suggestions from spell:suggestor spell:suggest-detailed.

params.param: The path to a file containing the dictionary.
The URI of the dictionary.

function.usage:
Dictionaries loaded with the spell:loadfunction are automatically added to the following collections:
http://marklogic.com/xdmp/documents
http://marklogic.com/xdmp/spell

function.name: insert
function.summary: Load the words in $dict into the dictionary at $uri. If there is no document at $uri a new one will be created. If there is a document at $uri it will be overwritten.

params.param: The URI of the dictionary.
A dictionary document.

function.name: add-word
function.summary: Add the word $word to the dictionary at $uri. If the word is already in the dictionary (case-sensitive), then this function throws an exception.

params.param: The URI of the dictionary.
The word to add.

function.name: remove-word
function.summary: Remove the word $word from the dictionary at $uri.

params.param: The URI of the dictionary.
The word to remove.

function.name: make-dictionary
function.summary: Creates a dictionary node from a sequence of words. Use spell:loadto load the dictionary node into the database as a dictionary.

params.param: The words from which to construct a dictionary.

function.name: is-correct
function.summary: Returns true() if the specified word is spelled correctly, otherwise returns false(). A word is considered to be spelled correctly if it is in the specified dictionary.

params.param: The URIs of the dictionarys to use.
The word to check.

function.usage: The spell:is-correctfunction is a built-in function and does not require the import modulestatement in the XQuery prolog.
function.example:
spell:is-correct("en-utf8.xml","occasionally")
=> true()

function.name: suggest
function.summary: Suggests a list of spellings for a word. Returns a sequence of the most likely spellings for the specified word.

params.param: The URIs of the dictionarys to use.
The word for which you get spelling suggestions.

The options node for this suggest operation. The default is (). The node for the spell:suggest options must be in the http://marklogic.com/xdmp/spellnamespace.
The spell:suggestoptions include:
<maximum>
Specifies the maximum number of suggestions to be returned. The default is 10.
<distance-threshold>
Specifies a cut off threshold for suggestions having a distance less than the gven number. The default is 100.

usage.p: The spell:suggestfunction is a built-in function and does not require the import modulestatement in the XQuery prolog.

The spell:suggestfunction only provides suggestions to words that are less than 64 characters in length; words 64 characters or longer return no suggestions. Also, it removes any dictionary entries that are 64 characters or more, so it will never return a suggestion with greater than 64 characters.

function.example:
spell:suggest("myDictionary.xml","occasionally")
=> occasionally occasional occasion occasions occasion's occasioned optionally educationally irrationally

spell:suggest("spell.xml", "albetros")
=> albatross abettors alders alters Albert's Elbert's allegros alder's Walters abettor's

function.name: levenshtein-distance
function.summary: Given two strings, returns the Levenshtein distance between those strings. The Levenshtein distance is a measure of how many operations it takes to transform a string into another string, and it is useful in determining if a word is spelled correctly, or in simply comparing how "different" two words are.

params.param: The first input string.
The second input string.

usage.p: The spell:levenshtein-distancefunction is a built-in function and does not require the import modulestatement in the XQuery prolog.
The spell:levenshtein-distancefunction throws an exception if one of the strings is 64 or more characters in length and the other is at least 1 character in length.

function.example:
spell:levenshtein-distance("albatros","albetros")
=> 1

spell:levenshtein-distance("cat", "cats")
=> 1

function.name: double-metaphone
function.summary: Given a word returns the two metaphone keys. The primary and secondary metaphone keys which represent the phonetic encoding of two words are returned as a sequence of two strings. Double metaphone is an algorithm based on phonetic sounds useful in providing data to spelling correction suggestions.

params.param: The word for phonetic matching.

function.usage: The spell:double-metaphonefunction is a built-in function and does not require the import modulestatement in the XQuery prolog.
function.example:
spell:double-metaphone("smith")
=> smo xmt

spell:double-metaphone("jones")
=> jns ans

function.name: suggest-detailed
function.summary: Suggests a list of spellings for a word. Returns a sequence of elements describing each suggestion, including the suggested word, the distance, the key distance, the word distance, and the levenshtein distance.

params.param: The URIs of the dictionarys to use.
The word for which you get spelling suggestions.

The options node for this suggest operation. The default is (). The node for the spell:suggest-detailedoptions must be in the http://marklogic.com/xdmp/spellnamespace.
The spell:suggest-detailedoptions include:
<maximum>
Specifies the maximum number of suggestions to be returned. The default is 10.
<distance-threshold>
Specifies a cut off threshold for suggestions having a distance less than the gven number. The default is 100.

usage.p: The spell:suggest-detailedfunction is a built-in function and does not require the import modulestatement in the XQuery prolog.

The spell:suggest-detailedfunction only provides suggestions to words that are less than 64 characters in length; words 64 characters or longer return no suggestions. Also, it removes any dictionary entries that are 64 characters or more, so it will never return a suggestion with greater than 64 characters.

function.example:
spell:suggest-detailed("myDictionary.xml","occasionally")
=> ()

spell:suggest("spell.xml", "albetros")
=> <spell:suggestion original="albetros" dictionary="spell.xml"> <spell:word distance="26" key-distance="0" word-distance="95" levenshtein-distance="2"> albatross </spell:word> </spell:suggestion>

function.name: load
function.summary: Load the file specified in $path to the thesaurus at $uri. Exisiting documents at $uri are overwritten.

params.param: The path to a file containing thesaurus entries.
The URI of a thesaurus document.

function.usage:
If $path contains XML that does not conform to the thesaurus schema, an error is raised. If $uri contains XML that does not conform to the thesaurus schema (located in
install_dir/Config/thesaurus.xsd), an error is raised.

function.name: insert
function.summary: Load the entries in $thsr into the thesaurus at $uri. If there is no document at $uri a new one will be created. If there is a document at $uri it will be overwritten.

params.param: The URI of a thesaurus document.
A thesaurus document.

function.usage:
If $uri contains XML that does not conform to the thesaurus schema (located in
install_dir/Config/thesaurus.xsd), an error is raised.
If $thsr contains XML that does not conform to the thesaurus schema, an error is raised.

function.name: set-entry
function.summary: Adds the entry $entry to the thesaurus at $uri.

params.param: The URI of a thesaurus document.
An entry to add to the thesaurus.

function.usage:
set the entry $entry in the thesaurus at $uri. If $entry does not contain a valid entry node, an error will be raised. If an entry matching $entry does not exist in the thesaurus, $entry is added to the thesaurus. If $entry contains XML that does not conform to the thesaurus schema (located in
install_dir/Config/thesaurus.xsd), an error is raised.
function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace thsr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus" at "/MarkLogic/thesaurus.xqy";
thsr:set-entry("/myThsrDocs/roget.xml", <entry xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus"> <term>Car</term> <synonym> <term>Ford</term> <part-of-speech>noun</part-of-speech> </synonym> <synonym> <term>automobile</term> <part-of-speech>noun</part-of-speech> </synonym> <synonym> <term>Fiat</term> <part-of-speech>noun</part-of-speech> </synonym> </entry>)

function.name: remove-term
function.summary: Removes all entries with term $term from the thesaurus document(s) at $uri.

params.param: The URI of the thesaurus document(s).
A term to remove from the thesaurus.

function.name: remove-entry
function.summary: Removes all entries that exactly match $entry from the thesaurus documents(s) at $uri.

params.param: The URI of the thesaurus document(s).
A thesaurus entry.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace thsr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus" at "/MarkLogic/thesaurus.xqy";
(: removes the second "Car" entry from the thesaurus document :) thsr:remove-entry("/myThsrDocs/roget.xml", thsr:lookup("/myThsrDocs/roget.xml","Car")[2])

function.name: add-synonym
function.summary: Adds a synonym to the specified thesaurus entry.

params.param: A thesaurus entry.
A synonym to add to a thesaurus entry.

function.usage: The synonym and the entry specified must conform to the thesaurus schema and must be namespace-qualified with the "http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus" namespace.
function.example: xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace thsr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus" at "/MarkLogic/thesaurus.xqy"; thsr:add-synonym(thsr:lookup("/myThsrDocs/roget.xml", "car")[1], <thsr:synonym> <thsr:term>Alfa Romeo</thsr:term> </thsr:synonym>)

function.name: remove-synonym
function.summary: Removes synonym $synonym from thesaurus entry $entry.

params.param: A thesaurus entry.
A synonym to add to a thesaurus entry.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace thsr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/thesaurus" at "/MarkLogic/thesaurus.xqy";
thsr:remove-synonym(thsr:lookup("/myThsrDocs/roget.xml", "car")[1], <thsr:synonym> <thsr:term>Fiat</thsr:term> </thsr:synonym>)

function.name: lookup
function.summary: Returns all entries for term $term in the thesaurus document(s) at $uri.

params.param: The URI of the thesaurus document(s).
A term to lookup in the thesaurus.

function.example: thsr:lookup("/myThsrDocs/thesaurus.xml", "weary") => returns the thesaurus entry for the term "weary"

function.name: query-lookup
function.summary: Returns a sequence of all entries that are found by looking up terms in the query and/or subqueries of $query in the thesaurus document(s) at $uri.

params.param: The URI of the thesaurus document(s).
A cts:query item from any of the cts:*-queryfunctions ( cts:word-query, cts:and-query, etc.).

function.name: expand
function.summary: Returns a query that searches for all the query strings specified in $query and their synonyms as found in $entries.

params.param: A cts:query item from any of the cts:*-queryfunctions ( cts:word-query, cts:and-query, and so on). Thesaurus expansion only occurs on an "unwildcarded" cts:query; it cannot expand "wildcarded" queries.
A sequence of thesaurus entries.
A new weight for the relevance ranking. If $new-weight is the empty sequence, then the relevance ranking is inherited from the parent query.

A minimum weight for the relevance ranking. If $min-weight is not the empty sequence then only queries with weight less than or equal to $min-weight will be expanded. Otherwise, all queiries are expanded.
A sequence of node restrictions. These restrictions must be nodes that can be found in a thesaurus entry (for example, <thsr:qualifier>birds</thsr:qualifier>).

function.name: create-trigger
function.summary: Creates a new trigger in the context database. Returns the trigger ID of the created trigger.

params.param: A unique name. If $trigger-name is not unique, an error is returned.
A description of the trigger.

The definition of an event that invokes the trigger module. Use
trgr:trigger-data-event or
trgr:trigger-database-online-event to construct this element.

The module to execute when the triggering event occurs. Use
trgr:trigger-module to construct this element.
Set to true if the trigger is enabled.
A sequence of permissions for the trigger. These permissions will determine which roles are permitted to modify the trigger.

Set to true if the trigger should be allowed to trigger itself for recursive changes on the same document. Set to false to prevent the trigger from triggering itself. If this parameter is not present, then its value is true.
The task priority for post-commit triggers. Either "normal" or "higher". If this parameter is not present, the value is "normal".

usage.p: Triggers must be created in the triggers database associated with the the content database to which the triggers apply. To determine the triggers database programatically, use xdmp:triggers-databasein the evaluation context of the content database, or xdmp:databasewith the database name listed as the triggers databasevalue in the Admin Interface under Databases > content_db_name.
Triggers are created in the http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers/directory, with the trigger ID completing the URI. This is the ID returned by trgr:create-trigger.

If a trigger named $trigger-name already exists, the exception TRGR-TNEXISTSis raised. You must use
trgr:remove-trigger to delete an existing trigger before recreating it.

Once a trigger is created, you can view it in the Admin Interface under the content database, in the Triggers Summary page (Databases > content_db_name> Triggers). If your trigger does not appear in Triggers Summary, trgr:create-triggerwas probably evaluated in the wrong database context.

function.name: trigger-set-name
function.summary: Changes the name of a trigger.

params.param: The current trigger name.
The new trigger name.

usage.p: Changes the name of a trigger from $trigger-name to $new-trigger-name.
This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger whose name is to be changed.
If no trigger trigger named $trigger-name exists, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-description
function.summary: Sets the description of the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.
The new trigger description.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger whose description is to be changed.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-enable
function.summary: Enables the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be enabled. If no trigger named $trigger-name exists, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-disable
function.summary: Disables the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be disabled. If no trigger named $trigger-name exists, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-module
function.summary: Sets or replaces the action module associated with the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

A module definition. Use
trgr:trigger-data-event to construct this parameter.

usage.p: When $trigger fires, $module is evaluated. Any module previously associated with $trigger is replaced when this function is called.
This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be modified.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-event
function.summary: Assigns a triggering event to the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

An event definition. Use
trgr:trigger-data-event or
trgr:trigger-database-online-event to construct this element.

usage.p: A trigger event describes the conditions under which the trigger fires. After calling this function, any previous event associated with the trigger is replaced.
This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be modified.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-permissions
function.summary: Sets the permissions that determine which roles are permitted to modify the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.
A sequence of permission nodes.

usage.p: Any permissions previously associated with the trigger are replaced.
This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be modified.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-get-permissions
function.summary: Returns the permissions for the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

usage.p: The permissions on a trigger determine which roles may modify the trigger. This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be examined.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-add-permissions
function.summary: Adds permissions to the set of permissions on the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.
A sequence of permission nodes.

usage.p: Any permissions previously associated with the trigger remain intact. This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be examined.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-remove-permissions
function.summary: Removes a set of permissions from the set of permissions on the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.
A sequence of permission nodes.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be modified.
Any permissions on $trigger-namenot listed in $permissionsare unchanged.
Any permissions in $permissionsnot associated with $trigger-nameare ignored.
If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: get-trigger
function.summary: Returns the XML representation of a trigger with the given name.

params.param: The trigger name.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be examined. If no trigger with the name $trigger-name exists, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: get-trigger-by-id
function.summary: Returns the XML representation of the trigger with the given trigger id.

params.param: The trigger id.

usage.p: This function must be run in the context of the database containing the trigger to be examined. If no trigger exists with id $trigger-id, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-module
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a trigger module which can be used as the moduleparameter of
trgr:create-trigger .

params.param: A database-id.
The root path within the database.
The path to the module relative to $root within the database identified by $database-id.

function.name: trigger-data-event
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a triggering eventa, usable as the eventparameter of
trgr:create-trigger .

params.param:
An event scope, such as is created by
trgr:directory-scope ,
trgr:collection-scope , or
trgr:document-scope .

An event part, such as is created by
trgr:document-content ,
trgr:property-content , or
trgr:any-property-content .

The timing of the trigger execution (pre- or post-commit). Use
trgr:post-commit or
trgr:pre-commit to construct this element.

usage.p: The scopeparameter describes the set of documents to which the trigger event applies. The contentparameter describes the interesting activity within scope, such as document creation or document property modification. The whenparameter describes when the event should be acted on, relative to the triggering transaction.

function.name: trigger-database-online-event
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a database coming online event, usable as the eventparameter of
trgr:create-trigger .

params.param: The user used to execute the trigger module.

function.name: document-scope
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a document scope, usable as the scope parameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

params.param: The document uri.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event(
trgr:document-scope("/myDir/interesting.xml"), trgr:document-content("modify"), trgr:post-commit())
=> A collection modification trigger event that may be used to create a trigger which fires whenever the document with URI /myDir/interesting.xml is modified.

function.name: collection-scope
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a collection scope, usable as the scope parameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

params.param: The collection uri.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event(
trgr:collection-scope("/myCollecion/"), trgr:document-content("modify"), trgr:post-commit())
=> A collection modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever the /myCollection/ collection is modified.

function.name: directory-scope
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a directory scope, usable as the scope parameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

params.param: The directory uri.
The depth of descendants included in the scope. ("1" or "infinity")

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event(
trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"), trgr:document-content("modify"), trgr:post-commit())
=> A directory modification trigger event that may be used to create a trigger which fires whenever the /myDir/ directory in a database is modified.

function.name: document-content
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a document part of a triggering event, usable as the content parameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

params.param: "create", "modify", or "delete"

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event( trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"),
trgr:document-content("modify"), trgr:post-commit())
=> A directory modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever the /myDir/ directory in the database is modified.

function.name: any-property-content
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of an all-properties part to a triggering event, usable as the content parameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

usage.p: Adding, changing or removing any document property matches this event part.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event( trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"),
trgr:any-property-content(), trgr:post-commit())
=> A property modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever any property is added, changed or removed on a document in the /myDir/ directory.

function.name: property-content
function.summary:
Returns the XML representation of a property part to a triggering event, usable as the contentparameter of a trigger event constructor such as
trgr:trigger-data-event .

params.param: The QName of the property.

usage.p: Adding, changing or removing the $property-name document property matches this event part.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:trigger-data-event( trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"),
trgr:property-content( fn:qname("", "myInterestingProperty")), trgr:post-commit())
=> A property modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever the property myInterestingProperty is added, modified or removed from a document in /myDir/.

function.name: pre-commit
function.summary: Returns the XML representation of a pre-commit trigger timing.

usage.p:
Use this function with
trgr:trigger-data-event to create a pre-commit trigger event. To learn more about pre-commit triggers, see "Using Triggers to Spawn Actions" in the Application Developer's Guide.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:post-commit()) trgr:trigger-data-event( trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"), trgr:document-content("create"),
trgr:pre-commit())
=> A document modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever a document is created in /myDir/. The associated trigger module executes before committing the firing document creation transaction.

function.name: post-commit
function.summary: Returns the XML representation of a post-commit trigger timing.

usage.p:
Use this function with
trgr:trigger-data-event to create a post-commit trigger event. To learn more about post-commit triggers, see "Using Triggers to Spawn Actions" in the Application Developer's Guide.

function.example:
xquery version "1.0-ml"; import module namespace trgr="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/triggers" at "/MarkLogic/triggers.xqy";
trgr:post-commit()) trgr:trigger-data-event( trgr:directory-scope("/myDir/", "1"), trgr:document-content("create"),
trgr:post-commit())
=> A document modification trigger event that can be used to create a trigger which fires whenever a document is created in /myDir/. The associated trigger module executes after committing the firing document creation transaction.

function.name: remove-trigger
function.summary: Removes the named trigger.

params.param: The trigger name.

usage.p: This function deletes the specified trigger. You must run this function to remove a trigger before recreating it. If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-recursive
function.summary: Sets the recursive setting of the identified trigger. When the recursive setting is true, the trigger will trigger itself for recursive changes to the same document.

params.param: The current trigger name.
The new recursive value for the specified trigger.

usage.p: If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: trigger-set-task-priority
function.summary: Sets the task priority setting of the identified trigger. The task priority is only applicable to post-commit triggers.

params.param: The current trigger name.
The new task priority value for the specified trigger. Either "normal" or "higher".

usage.p: If the named trigger does not exist, the exception TRGR-TRIGGERDNEis raised.

function.name: triggers-change-modules-database
function.summary: This function changes the trigger definitions of each trigger definition in the database that has the database ID $old-db and replaces each database ID with $new-db. This is useful after restoring a triggers database to a different cluster that has different database IDs than the one from which it was backed up.

params.param: The old database ID.
The new database ID.

function.name: any-custom-property-content
function.summary: This function....

function.name: validate-trigger-name
function.summary: This function....

params.param: Parameter description...

function.name: validate-data-event
function.summary: This function....

params.param: Parameter description...

function.name: validate-scope
function.summary: This function....

function.name: validate-content
function.summary: This function....

function.name: validate-when
function.summary: This function....

function.name: validate-database-online-event
function.summary: This function....

params.param: Parameter description...

function.name: validate-module
function.summary: This function....

params.param: Parameter description...

function.name: triggers-uri
function.summary: This function....

function.name: get-unique-trigger-id
function.summary: This function....

function.name: triggers-collection
function.summary: This function....

function.name: triggers-namespace
function.summary: This function....

function.name: url-encode
function.summary: Converts plaintext into URL-encoded string.

params.param: Plaintext to be encoded.
True to encode space as "%20" instead of "+".

function.example: xdmp:url-encode("Why not?") => "Why+not%3f"

function.name: url-decode
function.summary: Converts URL-encoded string to plaintext.

params.param: Encoded text to be decoded.

function.example: xdmp:url-decode("Why+not%3f") => "Why not?"

function.name: login

summary.p: Logs in a user on an application server that is using application-level authentication and sends a session cookie containing the session ID to the user's browser. Returns true on success, false on failure.

If the user calling this function has the xdmp:loginprivilege, this function can be called without a password or with the empty sequence as the password. In this case, login will succeed if the specified user exists. Therefore, use the xdmp:loginprivilege carefully, as any user with that privilege will be able to execute code that uses the xdmp:loginfunction to log in as any user.

params.param: The username of the user to be logged in.
The user's password. The password is not needed if the user calling the function has the xdmp:login execute privilege.
A boolean value specifying whether to set a session variable for the login. The default is true. Set to false to not set the session variable to maintain the user logged in.

usage.p: The session exists in the E-node on which it was created; you cannot access that session from a different E-node.

You can use the xdmp:set-session-fieldfunction to set a named value in the session and the xdmp:get-session-fieldfunction to return a value set in a session field. The user session expires when the session reaches its timeout limit. The session cookie remains on the browser until the browser exits or the cookie is explicitly removed by the user.

function.example: xdmp:login("mark","secret") => true() -- if user "mark" has password "secret"
xdmp:login("username") or xdmp:login("username", ()) => true() -- if user calling the function has the xdmp:login privilege
xdmp:login("username") or xdmp:login("username", ()) => SEC-PRIV exception if the user calling the function does not have the xdmp:login privilege
xdmp:login("username") => true() -- if current user has the xdmp:login privilege
xdmp:login("username") => SEC-PRIV exception if current user does not have the xdmp:login privilege

function.name: logout
function.summary: Logs the current user out of the session on the server. The result is that the current user is set to the default user defined in application-level authentication. The session remains on the server until it expires.
function.example: xdmp:logout() => ()

function.name: get-request-field-names
function.summary: Returns a sequence of the request field names.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-field-names() => ("section", "name", ...)

function.name: get-request-field
function.summary: Returns the value of a named request field. If the request field is a multipart/form-datatype in a POST form, you can use xdmp:get-request-fieldfor file upload applications (see the second examplebelow).

params.param: Request field name.
A default value to return if there is no request field.

function.example: xdmp:get-request-field("index") => "10"

Consider a form.xqy XQuery module with the following content:

Then have an upload.xqy XQuery module as follows: let $filename := xdmp:get-request-field-filename("upload") let $disposition := fn:concat("attachment; filename=""",$filename,"""") let $x := xdmp:add-response-header("Content-Disposition", $disposition) let $x:= xdmp:set-response-content-type( xdmp:get-request-field-content-type("upload")) return xdmp:get-request-field("upload") Execute the form.xqy file, select a file, and click the "Upload and Get Results" button. The file you uploaded will open according to the mime type the browser. If you wanted to save it to the database, you could use xdmp:document-insert to do so.

function.name: get-request-field-filename
function.summary: Returns a list of filenames from a multipart request for the field name specified. Returns an empty sequence for a field that does not exist.

params.param: The name of the request field with the multipart request.

function.usage: This function is useful for file upload applications. For an example, see the second example in the xdmp:get-request-fielddocumentation.
function.example: (: Returns the filename of the files loaded in the "upload" input form element. :) xdmp:get-request-field-filename("upload") => "myfile.doc"

function.name: get-request-field-content-type
function.summary: This function is used to extract the content type from the request field. It returns a sequence of content types, one for each filename, in the same order as the filenames returned from xdmp:get-request-field-filename.

params.param: The name of the request field with the multipart request.

function.usage: This function is useful for file upload applications. For an example, see the second example in the xdmp:get-request-fielddocumentation.
function.example: (: Returns the content type of the files loaded in the "upload" input form element. :) xdmp:get-request-field-content-type("upload") => "application/msword"

function.name: get-request-header-names
function.summary: Returns a sequence of request header names.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-header-names() => ("A", "B", ...)

function.name: get-request-header
function.summary: Returns the value of a named request header.

params.param: Request header name.
A default value to return if there is no request header.

function.example: xdmp:get-request-header("A") => "foo"

function.name: get-request-username
function.summary: Returns the username from the Authorizationheader of this App Server request.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-username() => "fred"

function.name: get-request-method
function.summary: Returns the HTTP request method.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-method() => "GET"

function.name: get-request-path
function.summary: Returns the HTTP request path.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-path() => "/example.xqy"

function.name: get-request-url
function.summary:
Returns the portion of the URL following the host_name:port_number. The output does not include any fragment identifier supplied with the URL (that is, it does not include the # sign or anything following the # sign). Note that when a URL rewriter is used, this function returns the rewritten URL. To get the URL before rewriting occurs, use
xdmp:get-original-url .
function.example: xdmp:get-request-url() => "/example.xqy?name=foo&year=2006"

function.name: get-original-url
function.summary:
Returns the portion of the URL following the host_name:port_number. The output does not include any fragment identifier supplied with the URL (that is, it does not include the # sign or anything following the # sign). Note that when a URL rewriter is used, this function returns the URL before rewriting occurs. To get the URL after rewriting occurs, use
xdmp:get-request-url .
function.example: xdmp:get-original-url() => "/example.xqy?name=foo&year=2006"

function.name: get-request-port
function.summary: Returns the port of the request.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-port() => 8000

function.name: get-session-field-names
function.summary: Returns a sequence of the HTTP session field names from the session created by the xdmp:loginfunction.
function.usage: You can use the xdmp:set-session-fieldfunction to set a named value in a session and the xdmp:get-session-fieldfunction to return a value set in a session field.
function.example: xdmp:get-session-field-names() => ("user", "role", "action", "index")

function.name: get-session-field
function.summary: Returns the value of a named session field from the session created by the xdmp:loginfunction.

params.param: The name of the session field.
A default value to return if there is no session field.

function.usage: You can use the xdmp:set-session-fieldfunction to set a named value in a session and the xdmp:get-session-field-namesfunction to return the names of the fields in the session.
function.example: xdmp:get-session-field("user") => "marklogic"

function.name: set-session-field
function.summary: Sets the value of a named session field for the session created by the xdmp:loginfunction.

params.param: The name of the session field.
The value of the session field.

function.usage: You can use the xdmp:get-session-field-namesfunction to return the names of the fields in the session and the xdmp:get-session-fieldfunction to return a value set in a session field.
function.example: xdmp:set-session-field("user", "marklogic") => "marklogic"

function.name: get-server-field-names
function.summary: Returns a sequence of the server field names.
function.usage: This functions returns the server field names of the fields for which you have privileges to see. Users with the adminrole have privileges to see all of the server fields. Application Services uses several protected server fields, each having a name that starts with "scope@". Therefore, if you are a user with the adminrole, you will see all of those fields when you call xdmp:get-server-field-names.
function.example: xdmp:get-server-field-names() => ("name1","name2")

function.name: get-server-field
function.summary: Returns the value of a named server field. A server field is created with xdmp:set-server-fieldand stores a name/value pair in memory. The server field is available on the App Server in which it is set on the host in which the App Server runs, via xdmp:get-server-field; a server field that is set on one App Server is not available on other App Servers on that host or on the same App Server running on another host. Server fields are commonly used with the system Plugin Framework.

params.param: The name of the server field.
A default value to return if there is no server field.

function.example: xdmp:get-server-field("foo") => "bar"

function.name: set-server-field
function.summary: Sets the value of a named server field. A server field is created with xdmp:set-server-fieldand stores a name/value pair in memory. The server field is available on the App Server in which it is set on the host in which the App Server runs, via xdmp:get-server-field; a server field that is set on one App Server is not available on other App Servers on that host or on the same App Server running on another host.

params.param: The name of the server field.
The value of the server field.

usage.p: If you use a server field with the system Plugin Framework (by placing the xdmp:set-server-fieldcode in a main module under the Pluginsdirectory on a host), then the server field will be populated for each App Server on the host before the first request against each App Server is run.
If you set a server field to the empty sequence, it deletes the server field and it will not appear when you run xdmp:get-server-field-names.

function.example: xdmp:set-server-field("foo", "bar") => "bar"

function.name: set-server-field-privilege
function.summary: Sets the privilege of a named server field.

params.param: The name of the server field.
The privilege action URI for the server field.

usage.p: Changing the server field value on a field being used with a plugin will change the behavior of the plugin. Therefore, if you are using a server field in a plugin, it is a good practice to set a privilege on the server field to protect it from malicious or accidental updates.

function.example: xdmp:set-server-field-privilege("foo", "http://mydomain.com/privileges/foo-server-field")

function.name: redirect-response
function.summary: Redirects the App Server response to a given location.

params.param: The redirect URL.

function.example: xdmp:redirect-response("http://marklogic.com/howtobuy.xqy")

function.name: set-response-code
function.summary: Sets the response code and message.

params.param: The response code.
The response message.

function.example: xdmp:set-response-code(204,"No Content")

function.name: get-response-code
function.summary: Returns two nodes, the first containing the HTTP response code and the second containing the HTTP response message.
function.usage: You can use this with an HTTP Server error handler to create custom error pages.
function.example: xdmp:response-code() => 200 OK

function.name: set-response-content-type
function.summary: Sets the response content-type.

params.param: The content type.

function.example: xdmp:set-response-content-type("text/html")

function.name: set-response-encoding
function.summary: Sets the response encoding.

params.param: The desired response encoding.

function.example: xdmp:set-response-encoding("ISO-8859-1")

function.name: get-response-encoding
function.summary: Returns the encoding that the response from this server is in.

function.name: set-request-time-limit
function.summary: Changes the time limit for an actively running request to the specified value. If you do not supply values for the last three parameters, the function sets the time limit for the current request.

params.param: The desired time limit, in seconds.

The ID of the host on which the request is running. Typically, you get the ID of a host by executing code similar to:
xdmp:host("myhost")

The ID of the App Server in which the request is running. Typically, you get the ID of an App Server by executing code similar to:
xdmp:server("myAppServerName")

The ID of the request. You can access the request IDs in the requestelements of the xdmp:server-statusoutput. You get the request ID by executing code similar to:
declare namespace status= "http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/server"
xdmp:server-status( xdmp:host("myhost"), xdmp:server("myAppServerName") )//status:request

privilege.p: http://marklogic.com/xdmp/privileges/xdmp-set-request-time-limit-anyor http://marklogic.com/xdmp/privileges/xdmp-set-request-time-limit-my

function.example: xdmp:set-request-time-limit(10000)

function.name: add-response-header
function.summary: Adds an HTTP response header field.

params.param: The response header name.
The value to set for this response header.

function.example: xdmp:add-response-header("meta", "description")

function.name: uri-is-file
function.summary: Returns true if a given URI refers to a file which exists on the current application server. Returns false if the file does not exist. Returns the empty sequence if the URI is the empty sequence.

params.param: The URI to check. If the URI begins with a "/", it is relative to the root directory of the application server. Otherwise, it is relative to the current request URI.

function.example: xdmp:uri-is-file("apppages/test.xml") => true if test.xml exists in "apppages" sub-directory relative to the directory of the file containing the request.
xdmp:uri-is-file("/sub-directory/test.xml") => true if test.xml exists in "sub-directory" relative to the root directory of the application server.

function.name: get-request-client-address
function.summary:
Returns as a string the internet address of the client from which the HTTP server request is issued.
Returns the empty sequence if it is not called from an HTTP server.
function.usage: Use this function if you need to get the internet protocol (IP) address of the requesting client. For example, you can create an application that contains conditional code based on IP addresses (see the example below).
function.example: xdmp:get-request-client-address() => "127.0.0.1"

function.name: get-request-protocol
function.summary:
Returns as a string the request protocol (either "http" or "https")
Returns the empty sequence if it is not called from an HTTP server.
function.usage: Use this function if you need to determine whether the client connection is HTTP or HTTPs.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-protocol() => "https"

function.name: get-request-client-certificate
function.summary:
Returns the PEM encoded client certificate if one was presented.
Returns the empty sequence if it is not called from an HTTP server, if SSL is not enabled for the HTTP server, or if no certificate is available. A clients will not send its certificate unless the server requests it.
function.usage: Use this function if you need to examine a client's certificate.
function.example: for $p in xdmp:get-request-client-certificate() return xdmp:x509-certificate-extract($p)

function.name: get-request-body
function.summary:
For PUT requests, returns the body of the request. For POST requests, returns the body of the request if it is not of content-type application/x-www-form-urlencoded.
Returns the empty sequence if it is not called from an application server.

params.param: The format ("xml", "text", or "binary") to interpret the body as. If not supplied, the format associated with the content-type header in mimetypes.xml is used. If no content-type header exists, the default format is "binary".

usage.p: If the content-type of the POST body is application/x-www-form-urlencoded, it is not available here, but instead is available in its decoded form through xdmp:get-request-field-names()and xdmp:get-request-field().

If there is no content-type header in the request, then the request body defaults to application/x-www-form-urlencoded, and therefore xdmp:get-request-bodywill return the empty sequence. If you want to read the request body, then the POST must include a content-type header.
You can use this function to process certain types of web service SOAP requests with MarkLogic Server.

The output of an xdmp:get-request-bodycall is typically a document node, so if you want to get the contents of the POST, you should add a /node()XPath step to the output. The contents of the document node could be a text node, an element node, or a binary node.

function.example: xdmp:get-request-body()/node() => "Contents of POST body."

function.name: get-url-rewriter-path
function.summary: Returns the URL of the URL rewriter handler for this application server. An empty string is returned if there is no rewrite handler.

usage.p: This function is useful for implementing a rewrite handler where you may want to resolve a location relative to the rewrite handler rather than to the specific request. This may be the case if the rewrite handler is acting as a delegator to known modules.

function.example: fn:resolve-uri("special-handler.xqy", xdmp:get-url-rewriter-path())

function.name: can-grant-roles
function.summary: Tests whether a user can grant or revoke a set of roles. Raises an error if the session user can not.

params.param: A set of role names

function.example: xdmp:can-grant-roles(("development", "qa"))

function.name: security-assert
function.summary: Tests whether the current user has at least one of a given set of privileges. Raises an error if the user does not have any of the privileges.

params.param: The set of privilege URIs. These are the action URIs for the privileges, not the names of the privileges.
The kind of privileges (either "execute" or "uri").

function.example: xdmp:security-assert("http://my-function/function-foo", "execute")

function.name: has-privilege
function.summary: Tests whether the current user has at least one of a given set of privileges. Returns true if they do, false otherwise.

params.param: The set of privilege URIs. These are the URIs for the privileges, not the names of the privileges.
The kind of privileges (either "execute" or "uri").

function.example: xdmp:has-privilege("http://myprivs/function-foo", "execute") => true if the current user has the execute privilege on a privilege with the URI "http://myprivs/function-foo"

function.name: user-roles
function.summary: Returns all roles assigned to a user, including roles directly assigned to the user and roles inherited by other roles.

params.param: The user name.

function.name: role-roles
function.summary: Returns the set of all roles inherited by a given role, including roles directly assigned to the role and roles inherited from other roles.

params.param: The role name.

function.name: privilege-roles
function.summary: Returns the set of all roles that have a given privilege.

params.param: The privilege action.
The privilege kind.

function.example: xdmp:privilege-roles( "http://marklogic.com/privileges/delete-all", "execute") =>(2349872340, 432987324)

function.name: amp-roles
function.summary: Returns the set of all roles assigned to an amp, including roles directly assigned to the amp and roles inherited by other roles.

params.param: The amped function namespace URI.
The amped function localname.
The amped function module URI.
The database ID containing the module.

function.example: xdmp:amp-roles("http://marklogic.com", "read-docs", "/app/docs.xqy", 239487239487) =>(2349872340, 432987324)

function.name: document-get-collections
function.summary: Returns the collections to which a given document belongs.

params.param: The document URI.

function.example: xdmp:document-get-collections("chapter5.xml") =>("http://marklogic.com/all-books", "http://marklogic.com/xml-books")

function.name: document-get-permissions
function.summary: Returns the permissions to a given document.

params.param: The document URI.

function.example: xdmp:document-get-permissions("chapter5.xml") =>(<sec:permission> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>324978243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>, <sec:permission> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>32493478578243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>, <sec:permission> <sec:capability>update</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>32493478578243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>)

function.name: default-permissions
function.summary: Returns the permissions any new document would get if the current user were to insert a document without specifying the default permissions.

params.param: The document URI to get parent directory.

function.example: xdmp:default-permissions("http://example.com/content/foo.xml") =>(<sec:permission> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>324978243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>, <sec:permission> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>32493478578243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>, <sec:permission> <sec:capability>update</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>32493478578243</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>)

function.name: default-collections
function.summary: Returns the collections any new document would get if the current user were to insert a document without specifying the collections.

params.param: The document URI to get parent directory.

function.example: xdmp:default-collections() =>("http://example.com/docs", "http://example.com/manuals")

function.name: get-current-user
function.summary: Returns the name of the current user.
function.example: xdmp:get-current-user() =>"ian"

function.name: get-request-user
function.summary: Returns the id of the current user.
function.example: xdmp:get-request-user() =>23987236

function.name: get-current-roles
function.summary: Returns all the current roles, both assigned and inherited by the current user and any received from amps.

function.name: permission
function.summary: Returns a permission element in the security namespace corresponding to the named role and capability given.

params.param: A role name.
A capability (read, update, insert, or execute).

function.example: xdmp:permission("development", "read") =><sec:permission> <sec:capability>read</sec:capability> <sec:role-id>32497824353</sec:role-id> </sec:permission>

function.name: user
function.summary: Returns the user ID for the specified user name. Unlike the security library module function sec:uid-for-name, this function can be evaluted against any database and does not need to be evaluated directly against the security database. It returns the user ID from the security database configured for the database in which the App Server evaluates against.

params.param: A user name.

function.example: xdmp:user("sylvester") => 239871567325

function.name: role
function.summary: Returns the role ID for the specified role name. Unlike the security library module function sec:uid-for-name, this function can be evaluted against any database and does not need to be evaluated directly against the security database. It returns the role ID from the security database configured for the database in which the App Server evaluates against.

params.param: A role name.

function.example: xdmp:role("editor") => 2392349873545

function.name: privilege
function.summary: Returns the privilege ID for the specified privilege name. Unlike the security library module function sec:uid-for-name, this function can be evaluted against any database and does not need to be evaluated directly against the security database. It returns the privilege ID from the security database configured for the database in which the App Server evaluates against.

params.param: A privilege action.
A privilege kind: "execute" or "URI".

function.example: xdmp:privilege("http://my-app/test","execute") => 2392349873545

function.name: amp
function.summary: Returns the amp ID for the specified amp. Unlike the security library module function sec:uid-for-name, this function can be evaluted against any database and does not need to be evaluated directly against the security database. It returns the amp ID from the security database configured for the database in which the App Server evaluates against.

params.param: A function namespace.
A function localname.
The module URI for the amp.
The ID of the database in which the module to which this amp refers is stored. If the module is on the filesystem under the Modulesdirectory, then specify 0 for the database ID.

function.example: xdmp:amp("http://my-app/test","my-func","/modules/my-module.xqy", xdmp:modules-database()) => 2392349873545
xdmp:amp("http://marklogic.com/xdmp/security", "amp-add-roles", "/MarkLogic/security.xqy", 0) => 3548369234520018804

function.name: host-status
function.summary: Returns the status of a host.

params.param: A host ID.

usage.p: The information returned from xdmp:host-statusis always computed on the host specified in the $host-idparameter, even if the call is evaluated on an App Server running on a different host. That is, when the API call is issued, MarkLogic Server communicates with the specified host for the its status and returns the staus from the perspective of the specified host (not from the perspective of the host in which the XQuery API is evaluated).

function.example: xdmp:host-status(xdmp:host("raymond.marklogic.com")) => <host-status xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/host"> <host-id>13264574555735898770</host-id> function.name: cache-status

function.name: forest-counts
function.summary: Returns detailed forest statistics for a given forest. This built-in may require significantly more processing time than xdmp:forest-status.

params.param: A forest ID.

The names of a elements to be returned (the element names are listed in the Usage Notes below). Only the top-level elements that show counts are allowed (for example, stands-countsor document-count). The function will only perform the computations necessary to return the nodes specified. If this parameter is not specified, then all statistics are calculated and returned for the forest. For each element name, you can specify a trailing * for wildcard matching. Specifying a * with no other text forces all calculations and returns all of the nodes.

function.example: xdmp:forest-counts(xdmp:forest("Documents")) => <forest-counts xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/forest"> <forest-id>12434840716430044697</forest-id> <current-time>2007-02-16T19:00:00.708-08:00</current-time> <stands-counts> <stand-counts> <stand-id>15174447282968484759</stand-id> <path>c:\Program Files\MarkLogic\Data\Forests\Documents\00000016</path> <active-fragment-count>146</active-fragment-count> <nascent-fragment-count>0</nascent-fragment-count> <deleted-fragment-count>0</deleted-fragment-count> </stand-counts> </stands-counts> <document-count>67</document-count> <directory-count>3</directory-count> </forest-counts>

(: only calculate the document count :) xdmp:forest-counts(xdmp:forest("Documents"), ("document-count")) => <forest-counts xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/forest"> <forest-id>11656884323633926637</forest-id> <forest-name>Documents</forest-name> <current-time>2008-03-18T16:22:34.082-07:00</current-time> <document-count>1070</document-count> </forest-counts>
(: force everything to be calculated :) xdmp:forest-counts(xdmp:forest("Documents"), "*") => the full output of xdmp:forest-counts

(: show the counts of everything that needs to be reindexed :) xdmp:forest-counts(xdmp:forest("Documents"), "reindex*") => <forest-counts xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/forest"> <forest-id>11656884323633926637</forest-id> <forest-name>Documents</forest-name> <current-time>2008-03-18T18:07:47.57-07:00</current-time> <reindex-refragment-fragment-count>0</reindex-refragment-fragment-count> <reindex-refragment-rate>0</reindex-refragment-rate> <reindex-fragment-count>0</reindex-fragment-count> ...... ..... all of the other reindex* elements ...... </forest-counts>

function.name: request-status

summary.p: Returns the status of a running request. If the request ID is that of the calling request, then no special permission is required. If the ID is for another request, then the calling request needs http://marklogic.com/xdmp/privileges/statuspermission.
The result of this builtin is exactly equivalent to xdmp:server-status(xdmp:host(), xdmp:server())//*:request-status[*:request-id = $req], where $reqis the ID of the request you are interested in.

In the 3.2 release this builtin is not cluster-aware, the first argument (host ID) must be the same as the value returned by xdmp:host(). If you wish to obtain the status of a request running on a remote host, use the code snippet above to obtain the request status using xdmp:server-status().

params.param: A host ID. Must be the ID of the local host.
A server ID (HTTP, XDBC, webDAV, or Task).
A request ID.

function.example: xdmp:request-status(xdmp:host(), xdmp:server(), xdmp:request()) => <request-status xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/server"> <request-id>6421977735636900809</request-id> <server-id>6693979901326946703</server-id> <host-id>2612493919508853477</host-id> <canceled>false</canceled> <modules>0</modules> <database>5184170867299910410</database> <root>c:/ml-danny\</root> <request-kind>invoke</request-kind> <request-text>/cq/eval.xqy?iefix.txt</request-text> <update>false</update> <start-time>2008-06-09T16:08:43.681-07:00</start-time> <time-limit>600</time-limit> <max-time-limit>1440</max-time-limit> <user>893641342095093063</user> <client-address>127.0.0.1</client-address> <trigger-depth>0</trigger-depth> <expanded-tree-cache-hits>0</expanded-tree-cache-hits> <expanded-tree-cache-misses>0</expanded-tree-cache-misses> <request-state>running</request-state> <profiling-allowed>true</profiling-allowed> <profiling-enabled>false</profiling-enabled> <debugging-allowed>true</debugging-allowed> <debugging-status>detached</debugging-status> </request-status>

function.name: foreign-cluster-status
function.summary: Returns the status of a foreign cluster from a host's point of view.

params.param: A host ID.
A foreign cluster ID.

function.example:
xdmp:foreign-cluster-status(xdmp:host(),xdmp:foreign-cluster("SanFrancisco")) =>
<foreign-cluster-status xmlns="http://marklogic.com/xdmp/status/foreign-cluster"> </foreign-cluster-status>

function.name: forest-backup
function.summary: Backs up forest data files.

params.param: A forest ID.

A forest backup pathname. If the directory does not exist, it is created when you run this function. The filesystem permissions must be such that the directory is writable by the operating system user under which MarkLogic Server is running. The directory cannot be the MarkLogic Server install directory or the MarkLogic Server data directory.

usage.p: Reindexing will stop while a backup or restore is in progress.

function.example: xdmp:forest-backup(11183608861595735720,"/backups/Data/Forests/Documents")

function.name: forest-restore
function.summary: Restores forest data files. Restarts the forest to complete the restoration.

params.param: A forest ID.
A forest backup pathname.

usage.p: Reindexing will stop while a backup or restore is in progress.

function.example: xdmp:forest-restore(11183608861595735720,"/backups/Data/Forests/Documents")

function.name: forest-clear
function.summary: Clears forest data files.

params.param: The IDs of the forests to clear. If a forest has replica forests, the replicas are cleared as well.

function.name: forest-restart
function.summary: Restarts a forest. If multiple forest IDs are specified, the restarts occur in parallel.

params.param: A forest ID.

function.name: forest-rollback
function.summary: Rolls forests back to a previous point in time, marking any fragment newer than the specified timestamp as deleted. Also, any fragments that were created before the specified timestamp and deleted after will be rolled back (un-deleted).

params.param: A sequence of forest IDs.
The system timestamp to which you want to roll back.

usage.p: If the timestamp specified is greater than the current system timestamp (that is, greater than the value of xdmp:request-timestamp()), then an exception is thrown.
If the specified timestamp is less than (earlier) then the the oldest timestamp in the specified forest(s), then an exception is thrown.
You should not have any updates occurring on a forest while it is being rolled back; the best practice is for the forest to be quiesced during a rollback operation.
If you have failover replication configured for a forest, the replica forest(s) will be rolled back at the same time as the specified forest(s).
If MarkLogic Server restarts during a rollback operation, the rollback will complete when the forest comes back online.
You can only roll back a forest that is in the "Open" state.
The updates-allowedsetting must be set to allin order to successfully roll a forest back to a previous timestamp.
As part of the xdmp:forest-rollbackoperation, the specified forest(s) are restarted.

As a consequence of the forest(s) restarting, if the forest is a failover forest and it is failed over to another host, the system will attempt to mount the forest on the original host (that is, it will un-failover the forest).

If you perform an xdmp:forest-rollbackoperation on a forest attached to the context database or any of its auxilliary databases (the security, modules, or triggers databases for that database), then the rollback is performed asyncronously in the background, and any exceptions that occur will not be reported back to the program; in this case, if an exception occurs it might be reported to the ErrorLog.txtfile. Additionally, because the rollback of forests in the context database (or in its auxilliary databases) is run asyncronously, there might be a small delay between when the rollback is issued and when the forest is restarted, and the rollback state is not reflected until the forest restart is completed. Therefore, it is best practice to call xdmp:forest-rollbackagainst forests not attached to the context database.
After an xdmp:forest-clearoperation on a forest, you will no longer be able to roll that forest back (because the forest clear deletes all of the stands in the forest).
The forest rollback operation cannot be undone (except by restoring from backup); that is, after rolling a forest back to a point in time, you cannot roll the forest "forward" to where you started.
